attributes.TEXT_IT: Io son la vita di Bonaventura / da BAGNOREGIO, che ne' grandi offici / sempre pospuosi la sinistra cura.

attributes.TEXT_EN: The one who lower down sits on the ground among them, looking up, is the marquis William for whom Alessandria and its war make MONFERRATO and Canavese weep.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Quel che pi√π basso tra costor s'atterra, / guardando in suso, √® Guiglielmo marchese, / per cui e Alessandria e la sua guerra / fa pianger MONFERRATO e Canavese.
attributes.Speaker: Sordello

attributes.TEXT_EN: But come along now, for Cain with his thorns now holds the boundary of the two hemispheres and touches the wave below SEVILLE
attributes.TEXT_IT: Ma vienne omai, ch√© gi√† tiene 'l confine / d'amendue li emisperi e tocca l'onda / sotto SOBILIA Caino e le spine
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: Bestial life pleased me, not human, mule that I was; I am Vanni Fucci the beast, and PISTOIA was a worthy lair for me.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Vita bestial mi piacque e non umana, / s√¨ come a mul ch'i'fui; son Vanni Fucci / bestia, e PISTOIA mi fu degna tana.
attributes.Speaker: Vanni Fucci

attributes.TEXT_EN: "Oh," said I to him, "I have never been through your lands; but where in all EUROPE does anyone dwell where they are not celebrated?
attributes.TEXT_IT: ‚ÄúOh!‚Äù diss' io lui, ‚Äúper li vostri paesi / gi√† mai non fui; ma dove si dimora / per tutta EUROPA ch'ei non sien palesi?
attributes.Speaker: Dante character

attributes.TEXT_EN: The cities of Lamone and SANTERNO are led by the lion cub in the white nest, who changes alliances between summer and winter.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Le citt√† di Lamone e di SANTERNO / conduce il l√Øoncel dal nido bianco, / che muta parte da la state al verno.
attributes.Speaker: Dante character

attributes.TEXT_EN: Arruns is the one who backs up against his belly there; in the mountains of LUNI, where the Carrarese hoes, who lives below.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Aronta √® quel ch'al ventre li s'atterga, / che ne' monti di LUNI, dove ronca / lo Carrarese che di sotto alberga
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: Oh happy HUNGARY if it lets itself be abused no further! And happy Navarre were it protected by the mount that girds it!
attributes.TEXT_IT: O beata UNGHERIA se non si lascia / pi√π malmenare! e beata Navarra, / se s'armasse del monte che la fascia!
attributes.Speaker: The Eagle of the blessed in the sky of Jupiter

attributes.TEXT_EN: With these Florentines I am a PADUAN: of then they thunder in my ears shouting: "Let the reigning knight come down
attributes.TEXT_IT: Con questi Fiorentin son PADOANO: / spesse f√Øate mi 'ntronan li orecchi / gridando: 'Vegna 'l cavalier sovrano
attributes.Speaker: (Rinaldo?) Scrovegni

attributes.TEXT_EN: Between the two shores of ITALY rise rocks, not far distant from your fatherland, so high that thunder sounds much lower
attributes.TEXT_IT: Tra ' due liti d'ITALIA surgon sassi, / e non molto distanti a la tua patria, / tanto che ' troni assai suonan pi√π bassi
attributes.Speaker: St. Peter Damian

attributes.TEXT_EN: And before I led the Greeks to the rivers of THEBES in my poetry, I was baptized; but out of fear I was a secret Christian
attributes.TEXT_IT: E pria ch'io conducessi i greci a' fiumi / di TEBE poetando, ebb' io battesmo; / ma per paura chiuso cristian fu'mi
attributes.Speaker: Statius

attributes.TEXT_EN: I was Italian, born of a great TUSCAN: Guglielmo Aldobrandesco was my father; I know not if his name was ever known to you.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Io fui latino e nato d'un gran TOSCO: / Guiglielmo Aldobrandesco fu mio padre; / non so se 'l nome suo gi√† mai fu vosco.
attributes.Speaker: Omberto Aldobrandesco

attributes.TEXT_EN: a hill rises up, and it does not become very high. FROM WHICH THERE ONCE CAME DOWN A BLAZING TORCH THAT MADE A GREAT ASSAULT UPON THE COUNTRYSIDE.
attributes.TEXT_IT: si leva un colle, e non surge molt' alto, / L√Ä ONDE SCESE GI√Ä UNA FACELLA / CHE FECE A LA CONTRADA UN GRANDE ASSALTO
attributes.Speaker: Cunizza da Romano

attributes.TEXT_EN: remember Pier of Medicina, if you ever return to see the lovely plain sloping down from Vercelli to MARCAB√í
attributes.TEXT_IT: rimembriti di Pier da Medicina, / se mai torni a veder lo dolce piano / che da Vercelli a MARCAB√í dichina.
attributes.Speaker: Pier da Medicina

attributes.TEXT_EN: and it was running against the heavens along those paths which the sun enflames when the ROMAN sees it set between the Sardinians and the Corsicans.
attributes.TEXT_IT: e correa contra 'l ciel per quelle strade / che 'l sole infiamma allor che quel da ROMA / tra ' Sardi e ' Corsi il vede quando cade.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: from which Perugia feels the cold and heat at Porta Sole, and behind it the heavy mountain yoke makes Nocera and GUALDO weep.
attributes.TEXT_IT: onde Perugia sente freddo e caldo / da Porta Sole; e di rietro le piange / per grave giogo Nocera con GUALDO.
attributes.Speaker: St. Thomas Aquinas

attributes.TEXT_EN: I was abbot in San Zeno in VERONA under the reign of the good Barbarossa, of whom Milan still speaks with grief.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Io fui abate in San Zeno a VERONA / sotto lo 'mperio del buon Barbarossa, / di cui dolente ancor Milan ragiona.
attributes.Speaker: Abbot of San Zeno
Penitent souls in the terrace of sloth

attributes.TEXT_EN: But let those ladies aid my verse who helped Amphion enclose THEBES, so that the word may not be different from the fact.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Ma quelle donne aiutino il mio verso / ch'aiutaro Anf√Øone a chiuder TEBE, / s√¨ che dal fatto il dir non sia diverso.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator
The Eagle of the blessed in the sky of Jupiter

attributes.TEXT_EN: Oh my brother, each of us is citizen of one true city; but you mean to say 'who lived in ITALY as a pilgrim.'
attributes.TEXT_IT: ‚ÄúO frate mio, ciascuna √® cittadina / d'una vera citt√†; ma tu vuo' dire / che vivesse in ITALIA peregrina.‚Äù
attributes.Speaker: Sap√¨a

attributes.TEXT_EN: O splendor of eternal, living light: who has become so pale beneath the shadow of PARNASSUS, or has drink so deeply from its well
attributes.TEXT_IT: O isplendor di viva luce eterna, / chi pallido si fece sotto l'ombra / s√¨ di PARNASO, o bevve in sua cisterna
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: though the custom is to take a single man, to preserve the peace; and we were such that it still appears around the GARDINGO.
attributes.TEXT_IT: ome suole esser tolto un uom solingo, / per conservar sua pace; e fummo tali, / ch'ancor si pare intorno dal GARDINGO.
attributes.Speaker: Fra Catalano

attributes.TEXT_EN: The old and young mastiff of Verrucchio, who guarded Montagna ill, as they are accustomed, make drills of their teeth.
attributes.TEXT_IT: E 'l mastin vecchio e 'l nuovo da VERRUCCHIO, / che fecer di Montagna il mal governo, / l√† dove soglion fan d'i denti succhio.
attributes.Speaker: Dante character

attributes.TEXT_EN: He who takes such short steps in front of me, all TUSCANY resounded with; now they hardly whisper of him in Siena.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Colui che del cammin s√¨ poco piglia / dinanzi a me, TOSCANA son√≤ tutta; / e ora a pena in Siena sen pispiglia
attributes.Speaker: Oderisi da Gubbio

attributes.TEXT_EN: which is called ACQUACHETA above, before it falls down into the low bed and loses its name at Forl√¨
attributes.TEXT_IT: che si chiama ACQUACHETA suso, avante / che si divalli gi√π nel basso letto, / e a Forl√¨ di quel nome √® vacante
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: And so I, speaking alone before the others, beg, if ever you see the land that sits between ROMAGNA and Charles's realm
attributes.TEXT_IT: Ond' io, che solo innanzi a li altri parlo, / ti priego, se mai vedi quel paese / che siede tra ROMAGNA e quel di Carlo
attributes.Speaker: Jacopo del Cassero

attributes.TEXT_EN: Oh! I said to him, "Are you not Oderisi, the honor of GUBBIO, and the honor of that art called illumination in Paris?"
attributes.TEXT_IT: ‚ÄúOh!‚Äù diss'io lui, ‚Äúnon se' tu Oderisi, / l'onor d'AGOBBIO e l'onor di quell' arte / ch'alluminar chiamata √® in Parisi?‚Äù
attributes.Speaker: Dante character

attributes.TEXT_EN: from which PERUGIA feels the cold and heat at Porta Sole, and behind it the heavy mountain yoke makes Nocera and Gualdo weep.
attributes.TEXT_IT: onde PERUGIA sente freddo e caldo / da Porta Sole; e di rietro le piange / per grave giogo Nocera con Gualdo.
attributes.Speaker: St. Thomas Aquinas

attributes.TEXT_EN: on THE BARE ROCK BETWEEN TIBER AND ARNO from Christ he then took the last seal, which his limbs bore for two years
attributes.TEXT_IT: nel CRUDO SASSO INTRA TEVERO E ARNO / da Cristo prese l'ultimo sigillo, / che le sue membra due anni portarno.
attributes.Speaker: St. Thomas Aquinas

attributes.TEXT_EN: We came up to it: O LOMBARD soul, how proudly and disdainfully you were holding yourself and how worthy and slow was the moving of your eyes!
attributes.TEXT_IT: Venimmo a lei: o anima LOMBARDA, / come ti stavi altera e disdegnosa / e nel mover de li occhi onesta e tarda!
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: And those of Portugal and NORWAY will be known there, and he of Rascia, who saw to his harm the coinage of Venice.
attributes.TEXT_IT: E quel di Portogallo e di NORVEGIA / l√¨ si conosceranno, e quel di Rascia / che male ha visto il conio di Vinegia.
attributes.Speaker: The Eagle of the blessed in the sky of Jupiter

attributes.TEXT_EN: And that noble shade, because of whom Pietola is more famous than any other MANTUAN village, had put off the burden I had laid upon him
attributes.TEXT_IT: E quell' ombra gentil per cui si noma / Pietola pi√π che villa MANTOANA, / del mio carcar diposta avea la soma
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: All those who in those times could bear arms, BETWEEN MARS AND THE BAPTIST, were a fifth of those alive today.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Tutti color ch'a quel tempo eran IVI / da poter arme TRA MARTE E 'L BATISTA, / erano il quinto di quei ch'or son vivi.
attributes.Speaker: Cacciaguida

attributes.TEXT_EN: So that its future crimes and those already done may seem less, I see the fleur-de-lis enter ANAGNI, and in his vicar Christ taken prisoner.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Perch√© men paia il mal futuro e 'l fatto, / veggio in ALAGNA intrar lo fiordaliso, / e nel vicario suo Cristo esser catto.
attributes.Speaker: Hugh Capet

attributes.TEXT_EN: But those of PROVENCE who worked against him do not laugh: thus he walks ill who feels harmed by the good another does.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Ma i PROVENZAI che fecer contra lui / non hanno riso; e per√≤ mal cammina / qual si fa danno del ben fare altrui.
attributes.Speaker: Justinian

attributes.TEXT_EN: If you just now fell into this blind world from that sweet ITALIAN earth whence I bring all my guilt
attributes.TEXT_IT: Se tu pur mo in questo mondo cieco / caduto se' di quella DOLCE TERRA / LATINA ond' io mia colpa tutta reco
attributes.Speaker: Guido da Montefeltro

attributes.TEXT_EN: Then he turned back, and he seemed one of those who at VERONA race for the green cloth across the fields; and of those he seemed the one who wins, not the one who loses.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Poi si rivolse e parve di coloro / che corrono a VERONA il drappo verde / per la campagna; e parve di costoro / quelli che vince, non colui che perde.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: That traitor who sees with only one eye, who holds THE CITY THAT MY FELLOW WISHES HE HAD STILL TO SEE
attributes.TEXT_IT: Quel traditor che vede pur con l'uno, e tien LA TERRA CHE TALE QUI MECO / VORREBBE DI VEDERE ESSER DIGIUNO
attributes.Speaker: Pier da Medicina

attributes.TEXT_EN: There she can be seen who pointed out LANGIA; Tiresias's daughter is there, and Thetis, and Deidamia with her sisters.
attributes.TEXT_IT: V√©deisi quella che mostr√≤ LANGIA; / √®vvi la figlia di Tiresia, e Teti, / e con le suore sue De√Ødamia.
attributes.Notes: Fount Langia is mentioned in Statius' Thebaid
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: for, as above its circling walls MONTEREGGIONE is crowned by towers, so there above the bank that circles the pit
attributes.TEXT_IT: per√≤ che, come su la cerchia tonda / MONTEREGGION di torri si corona, / cos√¨ la proda che 'l pozzo circonda
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: And, as soon as day was spent, it covered all the valley with fog, from PRATOMAGNO to the great yoke, and thickened the sky above it
attributes.TEXT_IT: Indi la valle, come 'l d√¨ fu spento, / da PRATOMAGNO al gran giogo coperse / di nebbia; e 'l ciel di sopra fece intento
attributes.Speaker: Buonconte da Montefeltro

attributes.TEXT_EN: As the Flemings, between WISSANT and Bruges, fearing the tide that rises against them, make dykes to escape the sea
attributes.TEXT_IT: Quali Fiamminghi tra GUIZZANTE e Bruggia, / temendo 'l fiotto che 'nver' lor s'avventa; / fanno lo schermo perch√© 'l mar si fuggia
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: Up in beautiful Italy there lies a lake, at the foot of the Alps that close in Germany above the TYROL, whose name is Benaco.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Suso in Italia bella giace un laco, / a pi√® de l'Alpe che serra Lamagna / sovra TIRALLI, c'ha nome Benaco.
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: it keeps falling, and THE MORE IT SWELLS, THE MORE THAT CURSED AND BALEFUL FURROW FINDS THE DOGS BECOMING WOLVES.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Vassi caggendo; e QUANT ELLA PI√ô 'NGROSSA, / TANTO PI√ô TROVA DI CAN FARSI LUPI / LA MALADETTA E SVENTURATA FOSSA.
attributes.Speaker: Guido del Duca

attributes.TEXT_EN: Hugh of Saint Victor is here with them, and Petrus Comestor and Peter of SPAIN, who shines down there in twelve volumes.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Ugo da San Vittore √® qui con elli, / e Pietro Mangiadore e Pietro SPANO, / lo qual gi√π luce in dodici libelli;
attributes.Speaker: St. Bonaventure

attributes.TEXT_EN: In the midst of the sea lies a ruined land, he said then, "called CRETE, under whose king the world once was chaste.
attributes.TEXT_IT: ‚ÄúIn mezzo mar siede un paese guasto,‚Äù / diss' elli allora, ‚Äúche s'appella CRETA, / sotto 'l cui rege fu gi√† 'l mondo casto.
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: had Holy Church in his embrace: he was from Tours, and by fasting he purges the eels of BOLSENA and the vernaccia.
attributes.TEXT_IT: ebbe la Santa Chiesa in le sue braccia: / dal Torso fu, e purga per digiuno / l'anguille di BOLSENA e la vernaccia.
attributes.Speaker: Forese Donati

attributes.TEXT_EN: Between the islands of CYPRUS and Maiolica Neptune has never seen so great a sin done, not by Argolians.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Tra l'isola di CIPRI e di Maiolica / non vide mai s√¨ gran fallo Nettuno, / non da pirate, non da gente argolica.
attributes.Speaker: Pier da Medicina

attributes.TEXT_EN: Then, near the time when all the heavens wished to reduce the world to their own serene measure, Caesar took it by the will of ROME.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Poi, presso al tempo che tutto 'l ciel volle / redur lo mondo a suo modo sereno, / Cesare per voler di ROMA il tolle.
attributes.Speaker: Justinian

attributes.TEXT_EN: Oh happy Hungary, if it lets itself be abused no further! And happy NAVARRE, were it protected by the mount that girds it!
attributes.TEXT_IT: O beata Ungheria, se non si lascia / pi√π malmenare! e beata NAVARRA / se s'armasse del monte che la fascia!
attributes.Speaker: The Eagle of the blessed in the sky of Jupiter

attributes.TEXT_EN: Not such harsh thickets nor so dense do those wild beasts hold, that hate the cultivated places between Cecina and CORNETO.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Non han s√¨ aspri sterpi n√© s√¨ folti / quelle fiere selvagge che 'n odio hanno / tra Cecina e CORNETO i luoghi c√≥lti.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: and WHERE SOLE AND CAGNANO COME TOGETHER, there is one who lords it and goes with head held high, and already they make the web to snare him.
attributes.TEXT_IT: e DOVE SILE E CAGNAN S'ACCOMPAGNA, / tal signoreggia e va con la testa alta, / che gi√† per lui carpir si fa la ragna.
attributes.Speaker: Cunizza da Romano

attributes.TEXT_EN: Then he said again: Let not your heart fear: henceforth I absolve you, if you teach me how to raze PALESTRINA to the ground.
attributes.TEXT_IT: E' poi ridisse: 'Tuo cuor non sospetti; / finor t'assolvo, e tu m'insegna fare / s√¨ come PENESTRINO in terra getti.
attributes.Speaker: Guido da Montefeltro

attributes.TEXT_EN: If one gathered together all the people who ever, on the travailed earth of APULIA, groaning poured forth their blood
attributes.TEXT_IT: S'el s'aunasse ancor tutta la gente / che gi√†, in su la fortunata terra / di PUGLIA, fu del suo sangue dolente
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: Nor do I alone need your reply, for all these have greater thirst for it than ever INDIAN or Ethiop for cold water.
attributes.TEXT_IT: N√© solo a me la tua risposta e uopo; / ch√© tutti questi n'hanno maggior sete / che d'acqua fredda INDO o Et√Øopo.
attributes.Speaker: Guido Guinizzelli

attributes.TEXT_EN: All bloodied he comes forth from THE WICKED WOOD; he leaves it such that a thousand years from now it will not be reforested to its original state.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Sanguinoso esce de LA TRISTA SELVA; / lasciala tal, che di qui a mille anni / ne lo stato primaio non si rinselva.
attributes.Speaker: Guido del Duca

attributes.TEXT_EN: which is called Acquacheta above, before it falls down into the low bed and loses that name at FORL√å
attributes.TEXT_IT: che si chiama Acquacheta suso, avante / che si divalli gi√π nel basso letto, / e a FORL√å di quel nome √® vacante
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: Already the sun had reached that horizon whose meridian circle covers JERUSALEM with its highest point.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Gi√† era 'l sole a l'orizzonte giunto / lo cui merid√Øan cerchio coverchia / IERUSAL√àM col suo pi√π alto punto
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: I was from there; but the deep holes through which my heart's blood poured put, were given me IN THE BOSOM OF THE ANTENORI
attributes.TEXT_IT: Quindi fu' io; ma li profondi f√≥ri / ond' usc√¨ 'l sangue in sul quale io sedea, / fatti mi fuoro in grembo a li ANTENORI
attributes.Speaker: Jacopo del Cassero

attributes.TEXT_EN: in the first circle of the blind prison; often times we speak about THE MOUNTAIN THAT FOREVER HOLDS OUR NURSES.
attributes.TEXT_IT: nel primo cinghio del carcere cieco; / spesse f√Øate ragioniam del MONTE / CHE SEMPRE HA LE NUTRICE NOSTRE SECO.
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: You know that it dwelt in ALBA for three hundred years and more until, finally, the three fought against the three for its possession.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Tu sai ch'el fece in ALBA sua dimora / per trecento anni e oltre, infino al fine / che i tre a' tre pugnar per lui ancora.
attributes.Notes: Destroyed in VII cent. BC, location approximate (ancient Latium)
attributes.Speaker: Justinian

attributes.TEXT_EN: The new people and the rapid gains have generated pride and excess, FLORENCE, in you, so that you already weep for it.
attributes.TEXT_IT: ‚ÄúLa gente nuova e i s√πbiti guadagni / orgoglio e dismisura han generata, / FIORENZA, in te, s√¨ che tu gi√† ten piagni.‚Äù
attributes.Speaker: Dante character

attributes.TEXT_EN: Therefore I advise you, if you ever hear any other origin given for MY CITY, that you let no lie defraud the truth.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Per√≤ t'assenno che, se tu mai odi / originar LA MIA TERRA  altrimenti, / la verit√† nulla menzogna frodi.
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: but before the GASCON shall deceive the noble Harry, sparke of his valor will appear, in his indifference to money and to toil.
attributes.TEXT_IT: ma pria che 'l GUASCO l'alto Arrigo inganni, / parran faville de la sua virtute / in non curar d'argento n√© d'affanni.
attributes.Speaker: Cacciaguida

attributes.TEXT_EN: Between Tupino and the stream that descends from the hill chosen by the blessed Ubaldo, there slopes THE FERTILE SIDE OF A HIGH MOUNTAIN.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Intra Tupino e l'acqua che discende / del colle eletto dal beato Ubaldo, / FERTILE COSTA D'ALTO MONTE pende,
attributes.Speaker: St. Thomas Aquinas

attributes.TEXT_EN: Its head, which spreads out more the more it goes up, would be admired by the HINDUS in their woods for its height.
attributes.TEXT_IT: La coma sua, che tanto si dilata / pi√π quanto pi√π √® s√π, fora da l'INDI / ne' boschi lor per altezza ammirata.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: Within the mountain stands erect a great old man, with his back toward DAMIETTA, looking toward Rome as to his mirror.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Dentro dal monte sta dritto un gran veglio, / che tien volte le spalle inver' DAMMIATA / e Roma guarda come s√ºo speglio.
attributes.Speaker: Virgil

attributes.TEXT_EN: As snow on the living beams along THE BACK OF ITALY turns to ice, driven and compressed by the Slavic winds
attributes.TEXT_IT: S√¨ come neve tra le vive travi / per LO DOSSO D'ITALIA si congela, / soffiata e stretta da li venti schiavi
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: Your first refuge and frst shelter will be the courtesy of the great Lombard who atop the ladder beats the holy eagle
attributes.TEXT_IT: Lo primo tuo refugio e 'l primo ostello / sar√† la cortesia del gran LOMBARDO / che 'n su la scala porta il santo uccello
attributes.Speaker: Cacciaguida

attributes.TEXT_EN: And the friar: "In BOLOGNA I once heard many vices of the devil told, among which I heard that he is a liar and the father of lies."
attributes.TEXT_IT: E 'l frate: ‚ÄúIo udi' gi√† dire a BOLOGNA / del diavol vizi assai, tra ' quali udi' / ch'elli √® bugiardo e padre di menzogna.‚Äù
attributes.Speaker: Fra Catalano

attributes.TEXT_EN: ROME, which made the good world, used to have two suns that made visible the two paths, of the world and of God.
attributes.TEXT_IT: Soleva ROMA, che 'l buon mondo feo, / due soli aver, che l'una e l'altra strada / facean vedere, e del mondo e di Deo.
attributes.Speaker: Marco Lombardo

attributes.TEXT_EN: THE MOUNTAIN THAT BEARS CASSINO ON ITS SIDE was once frequented, at the summit, by folk deceived and ill disposed.
attributes.TEXT_IT: QUEL MONTE A CUI CASSINO √à NE LA COSTA / fu frequentato gi√† in su la cima / da la gente ingannata e mal disposta
attributes.Speaker: St. Benedict

attributes.TEXT_EN: As one who comes, perhaps from Croatia, to see OUR VERONICA, who because of his ancient hunger is not sated
attributes.TEXT_IT: Qual √® colui che forse di Croazia / viene a veder LA VERONICA NOSTRA, / che per l'antica fame non sen sazia
attributes.Notes: Where the Veronica was held in Rome
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: And when Fortune leveled to the ground the pride of the TROJANS, all aflame, so that along with his kingdom the king was broken
attributes.TEXT_IT: E quando la fortuna volse in basso / l'altezza de' TROIAN che tutto ardiva, / s√¨ che 'nsieme col regno il re fu casso
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: suffered no more hatred from Leander when the sea was high between SESTOS and Abydos, than that river from me for not opening then.
attributes.TEXT_IT: pi√π odio da Leandro non sofferse / per mareggiare intra SESTO e Abido, / che quel da me perch' allor non s'aperse.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: And I to him: "What force or chance carried you away from CAMPALDINO, so that your burial place was never known?"
attributes.TEXT_IT: E io a lui: ‚ÄúQual forza o qual ventura / ti trav√Ø√≤ s√¨ fuor di CAMPALDINO, / che non si seppe mai tua sepultura?‚Äù
attributes.Speaker: Dante character

attributes.TEXT_EN: And the ancient ROMAN women were content with water for their drink; and Daniel scorned food but acquired knowledge.
attributes.TEXT_IT: E le ROMANE antiche, per lor bere, / contente furon d'acqua; e Dan√Øello / dispregi√≤ cibo e acquist√≤ savere.
attributes.Speaker: A voice from the tree in the terrace of gluttony

attributes.TEXT_EN: never did it show so many pestilences nor so poisonous, together with all ETHIOPIA and what lies beyond the Red Sea.
attributes.TEXT_IT: n√© tante pestilenzie n√© s√¨ ree / mostr√≤ gi√† mai con tutta l'ET√èOPIA / n√© con ci√≤ che di sopra al Mar Rosso √®e.
attributes.Speaker: Dante narrator

attributes.TEXT_EN: Between the islands of CYPRUS and Maiolica Neptune has never seen so great a sin done, not by ARGOLIANS.

attributes.TEXT_EN: who should have said: 'I did wrong' rather than, keeping the promise, doing worse. And you will find the great leader of the GREEKS to have been a blockhead.

attributes.TEXT_EN: that this generous priest will give over to prove he is a Guelph, and such gifts will conform to the ways of THAT LAND.

attributes.TEXT_EN: the citizens of THE DIVIDED CITY; if any there is just; and tell me the reason so much discord has assailed it.

attributes.TEXT_EN: the body from which it was driven lies down below in CIELDAURO, and from martyrdom and exile it came to this peace.

attributes.TEXT_EN: After the DOLOROUS ROUT, when Charlemagne lost the holy company, Roland did not sound his horn so terribly.

attributes.TEXT_EN: THE CITY THAT UNDERWENT THE LONG TRIAL AND MADE A BLOODY HEAP OF THE FRENCH, now finds itself beneath the green claws.

attributes.TEXT_EN: Between LERICI and Turb√¨a the wildest, the most broken landslide is a stairway open and easy, next to this one.

attributes.TEXT_EN: There was pictured the high glory of the ROMAN prince whose worth inspired Gregory to his great victory

attributes.TEXT_EN: A thousand springs, I think, and more, bathe the land between Garda and Val Camonica and the ALPS, with the water that collects in

attributes.TEXT_EN: And I said to my poet: "Now was there ever a people so foolish as the Sienese? Certainly not the FRENCH, by far!
